titleStmt.title: TO MY NOBLE FRIENDS, Mr RICHARD ROBINSON, And Mr MICHAEL BOWYER.
titleStmt.author: Davenport, Robert

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: TO MY NOBLE FRIENDS, Mr RICHARD ROBINSON, And Mr MICHAEL BOWYER.
analytic.author: Davenport, Robert

monogr.title: A crovvne for a conquerour : and too late to call backe yesterday. Two poems, the one divine, the other morall. By R.D
monogr.author: Davenport, Robert

div.head: TO MY NOBLE FRIENDS, Mr RICHARD ROBINSON, And Mr MICHAEL BOWYER.

p.hi:
THese Poems (true and Noble Friends) being some expence of my time at Sea, I have thus habited, to present them as my true love to you on the Land. In one morning J present you with two poems. They are Virgins that never before kist the Presse, yet now come ready prest to kisse your hands. J have phrased them rather with a native familiarity, then an impertinent Elegancy, least by disregulating Art, J had made nature monstrous. Yet where the dignity of the subiect duely invites a higher-valued language, J have (to my ability) endeavored
a redemption. Were I versd in the tricke of flattery, I should have Deckt my dedication with some protestations of your worthinesse and my love But I suppose honest faithfulnesse rather blemished then embellishedwith those adulterated beauties; Favour mee to read this Messenger of my love; and more, to Accept it as the fruites of those faire respects in which (as J euer was) I am alwaies,

closer.signed: At your commandement a servant, ROB. DAVENPORT.
